title: Kevin G. Daly: Ruminant Palaeogenomics
text:
Hello!


 My group’s research interests are the consequences of ruminant domestication and human activity.  We study this using palaeogenomics - genome data recovered from thousands of years old bones, teeth, and other materials.  With these ancient genomes, we can peak back into prehistory to see how animals have evolved, what were past patterns of biodiversity and how they have changed, and the forces shaping modern animal diversity.

title: Kevin G. Daly: Ruminant Palaeogenomics
text:
Who we are


From February 2024 I have set up a research group at University College Dublin, in the UCD School of Agriculture and Food Science.  Together with Louis L’Hôte (PhD student) we are exploring the deep history of ancient animal genetic diversity, health, pathogens and how both were shaped by domestication and human activity as part of the SFI Pathways project “Herd Health”. In particular we focus on sheep and goats - small ruminants domesticated in Southwest Asia roughly 10,000 years ago.




The group at TCD, 2023 - new image to come

title: Contact
text: You can contact me (Kevin) at: kevin[at]palaeome.org or kevin.daly[at]ucd.ie

title: People
text:
Group Leader: Kevin Daly


Hello!
I am an Ad Astra Fellow - Lecturer/Assistant Professor at UCD’s School of Agriculture and Food Science, where I will lead the self-styled “Ruminant Palaeogenomics” group.


A standard working from home day.


I completed my undergraduate at Trinity College Dublin, where I began my academic career under the mentorship of Prof. Daniel Bradley. As part of Dan’s ERC project “CODEX” I generated the first large scale genomic dataset of an ancient livestock, thus beginning my minor obsession and healthy research interest in goats.
Following my PhD I had the fortunate to collaborate with Dr. Melinda Zeder on material from Ganj Dareh, one of the earliest settlements with robust evidence for goat management. Expanding the dataset of goat remains with Dr. Marjan Mashkour, Dr. Pernille Bangsgaard, and Dr. Lisa Yeoman, we created a multi-disciplinary collaboration on the world’s old managed goat herds, producing a study I am very proud of.
I have also explored the genomics of ancient sheep, a species arguably more important than goats but perhaps less charismatic. See here for a sheep mummy genome, from a specimen we thought was initially goat, led by the peerless Dr. Conor Rossi.
More recently I have been awarded an SFI Pathways award to explore small ruminant pathogens in the earliest phases of livestock domestication.
I am a member of the first cohort of the Young Academy of Ireland, the least among an exceptional group of young researchers and leaders.
I am a proponent to alternative peer review publishing models, and have submitted manuscripts through the “Peer Community In” system. I look forward to doing so again and hope to support the movement in any way I can.
In my free time I watch films and maintain a list of the best goat roles in cinema. You won’t believe what’s at number one!

title: People
text:
Postdoctoral Researchers

Jolijn Erven


Hello!
I’m Jolijn Erven, a Postdoc in Daly’s Ruminant Palaeogenomics working group.
I completed my master’s training in genetics at Wageningen University, where I strengthened my fascination with animal domestication, evolution, and behaviour.






This interest led me to pursue a PhD at the Groningen Institute of Archaeology, where I worked on the EDAN project.
There, I focused on the domestication processes of cattle and pigs in the Netherlands—and more broadly, Europe—using palaeogenomics to understand how early communities shaped, and were shaped by, the animals they lived alongside.
I am currently exploring the demographic history of domestic goats by studying early herding societies and the dispersal from early domestication centres.
I’m particularly keen on using every tool in our bioinformatics toolbox to better understand demographic shifts and evolutionary processes throughout the past.






I’m especially interested in multidisciplinary approaches—drawing from various fields to trace the origins and adaptations of domestic animals.
More broadly, I’m curious about how animals evolve in response to human or natural environments, and how behaviour, ecology, and genetics intersect in that story.
I strongly believe in the power of interdisciplinary collaboration and enjoy connecting data from different sources to answer long-standing questions about past demographic history.
When I’m not in the lab or wrangling data, I love sharing quirky animal trivia—or just talking your ears off about animals and/or bioinformatics tools.

title: People
text:
PhD Students

Louis L’Hôte


  I am Louis, PhD student in ancient pathogen genetics.
After a undegraduate degree in life science i followed a Master in Engineering in Microbiology at the Faculté des sciences et technologies, Université de Lorraine. Throughout my master degree i got the chance to be part of different research project: In 2021 i worked ancient woolly mammoth microbiota at the Microbial Palaeogenomics Unit of the Pasteur institute in Paris. 




This experience gave me the opportunity to learn a lot about metagenomics techniques and ancient DNA. It is why in 2022 i decided to do my master thesis in Copenhagen in the Centre for ExoLife Sciences (CELS) where i used metagenomics and metatranscriptomics techniques to understand how microbes are surviving in Mars-like extreme environment.       I am currently Kevin Daly’s PhD student and part of the SFI Pathways project “Herd Health” . Livestock animals were domesticated 10 000 years ago in southwest Asia, but little is known about their health (inbreeding, infectious disease) despite their underpinning of farmer societies . In the last few years, the advancement of Next generation sequencing techniques has made it possible to reconstruct different genomes of ancient human pathogens from archaeological specimens, such as Yersinia pestis, the agent of the Black Death . So far, the reconstruction of pathogen genomes has mainly been performed on human pathogens . My work focuses on obtaining pathogen and animal DNA from 10,000 years old sheep and goat material, from the Zagros Mountain in Iran, in order to understand how sheep and goat zoonotic pathogen evolution was shaped by the onset of domestication .
I’m interested in everything to do with microbes. From ancient DNA to wet lab.


Luisa Sacristán


¡Hola! I’m Luisa, and since 2025 I’ve been a PhD student in Kevin Daly’s Ruminant Palaeogenomics group at UCD’s School of Agriculture and Food Science.
I completed my undergraduate degree in Microbiology at the Universidad de Pamplona, Colombia and worked for three years as a quality control microbiologist. In 2020, I started working at Gencore, a sequencing core facility at Universidad de los Andes, where I participated in multiple projects focused on sequencing a wide variety of organisms and microorganisms. Additionally, during the pandemic, I had the honor of joining the COVIDA project and later contributed to the sequencing and genomic surveillance efforts in collaboration with Colombia’s National Institute of Health contributing to the detection and analysis of SARS-CoV-2 variants. During this time, I gained experience in molecular biology techniques and different sequencing technologies.
The challenge of generating biological data without knowing how to analyze it motivated me to pursue a Master’s degree in Computational Biology at Universidad de los Andes in 2022 joining the Computational Biology and Microbial Ecology (BCEM) group, where I developed strong skills in biological data analysis. As part of my master’s studies, I contributed to the development of a low-cost protocol for full operon sequencing using ONT sequencing to identify bacterial communities. Additionally, I had the wonderful opportunity to join the Beasts to Craft project, where I conducted my thesis research focused on metagenomic analysis of bacterial communities found in parchment from historical manuscripts and comparative genomics of pathogens recovered from these materials.
After completing my master’s, in 2024 I joined the CABANA project, developing and adapting bioinformatics e-learning courses in both spanish and english aiming to reduce language barriers in Latin America.
Currently, I am working on my PhD project, which aims to study the co-evolution of livestock and their pathogens by analyzing both the genomes of recovered pathogens and their host animals. (More details coming soon!)

title: Opportunities
text:
If you are interested in joining a recently-formed group and studying the evolution and dynamics of ancient domesticates with palaeogenomics - come work with me!
For those interested in writing a funding application for PhD (i.e. IRC) or postdoctoral funds (i.e. MCRA), please email me at kevin.daly[at]ucd.ie.
